Authors:
Jillian D. Bainard, Steven G Newmaster, Jessica M.
Budke
Title:
Genome size and endopolyploidy evolution across the moss
phylogeny
Keywords:
bryophytes, endopolyploidy, endoreduplication, flow
cytometry, genome size, mosses, phylogenetic signal, phylogenetic
independent contrasts (PIC).
Abstract:
 Compared to other plant lineages mosses appear to have
constrained genome sizes. This study determines the extent of DNA
content variation in mosses over a broad taxonomic sampling; examining
both genome size and endopolyploidy.  Moss samples were collected in
Canada and flow cytometry was used to determine genome size and
endoreduplication index (EI). A phylogenetic tree was constructed from
Genbank sequences and used to evaluate DNA content evolution in a
phylogenetic context by mapping genome size and EI across the tree and
testing for phylogenetic signal.  New genome size estimates and EI are
reported for 60 moss samples, representing 56 species from 20 families.
In combination with data from the literature, genome sizes were mapped
onto a phylogeny for 173 moss species. Genome size and EI have
significant phylogenetic signal when evaluated independently across the
phylogeny. When tested using phylogenetically corrected values, genome
size and EI were found to be significantly correlated.  Significant
phylogenetic signal indicates closely related mosses have similar genome
sizes and endoreduplication index values. Even across a constrained
range of genome sizes, mosses with smaller genomes had higher levels of
endopolyploid nuclei, compared to mosses with larger genomes when taking
phylogenetic distance into account.
